content: Look for symptoms of hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anal canal that can be present either outside or inside the body. They form when too much pressure on on the veins causes them to swell. [2] This can happen when you strain while having a bowel movement, during pregnancy, or as a result of being overweight. Hemorrhoids are a common condition that can often be resolved with home treatment, including witch hazel. Symptoms include the following: [3] Itching, irritation or pain in the anal area. Bleeding when you have a bowel movement (the blood will be bright red). A swelling or lump in the anal area. Check with your doctor before trying home treatment if you are unsure whether your symptoms are the result of hemorrhoids. Clean your anal area before treating your hemorrhoids. Bathe or shower daily to keep your anal area clean. Baths are preferable to showers because it allows the area to sit in warm water for longer. You don't need to use soap, but use warm to hot water. Be gentle when cleaning your anal area, as scrubbing harder can cause irritation. [4] Try a sitz bath to make things easier. These are inexpensive tubs that fit over your toilet to make it easier to soak your anal area. Use plain warm water or add Epsom salt to help soothe your hemorrhoids. Then, sit in your sitz bath for 10-15 minutes. Don't use a towel to dry your anal area because it can hurt. After drying off the rest of your body, use a hair dryer to dry off your anal area. Hold the hair dryer at least 8 inches (20 cm) away from your skin and keep it moving. Rubbing with a towel can make the problem worse. [5] Don’t direct the hair dryer at 1 spot, as this might burn your skin. Use a cloth to blot the witch hazel directly onto your hemorrhoid. Use a clean piece of cloth. Soak it in a witch hazel-alcohol extract. Blot it gently on the affected area. You can hold it on for a few minutes. [6] If you prefer, you can use pre-made witch hazel pads, made specifically for use with hemorrhoids. [7] This application is best for external hemorrhoids, as it only reaches the outer part of your anus. Internal hemorrhoids are ones that remain inside your anal cavity, while external ones bulge out past your sphincter. [8] Let the area air dry for a few minutes before getting dressed. Once you remove the cloth, let the area air dry for a few minutes before putting your clothes back on. If you put your clothes on over wet skin, it may not dry all of the way. Wear cotton underwear because it’s more breathable. Mix a teaspoon of witch hazel tincture with a teaspoon of cocoa butter. In a small bowl, place a teaspoon each of witch hazel tincture and cocoa butter. Stir them together. You should be able to find both at your local drug store, though you may need to visit a natural health store instead. [9] This application works best for internal hemorrhoids. You can use this treatment three times a day. [10] Form the mixture into a suppository. Shape the mixture into a small pill oblong pill shape. If you're having trouble shaping it, place the mixture in a small amount of plastic wrap, and twist the plastic wrap to shape the pill. If it's not in plastic wrap, place it in a small, covered bowl. [11] Freeze the suppository for at least 1-2 hours. Put the suppository on a clean dish. Then, set it in your freezer and leave it there until it’s frozen. This should take at least 1-2 hours, but it could take longer. [12] Put on a glove or finger cot. Wear hand protection to keep your fingers germ-free. This step is optional, but it will help prevent you from getting bacteria under your nails or in the folds of your skin. [13] You don't have to use one, as long as you wash your hands thoroughly afterwards. Remove the suppository from the freezer. Once the suppository has hardened, take it out of the freezer. Unwrap it if it's in plastic wrap, or take the lid off the bowl. If it seems too large, you can cut it in half, and save half for another time by putting it back in plastic wrap and back in the freezer. [14] Use lubrication to make the suppository go in easily. Either apply a lubrication such as KY Jelly, or use your finger to wet your anal area with a little bit of cold water. This will help you avoid any discomfort when you insert the suppository. Plus, it will go in further. [15] Lie down on your side and open your buttocks. Lay down on your side. Bend the knee of your top leg, and angle it towards the bed. Let the other leg stay out straight. Use one hand to lift up one side of your buttocks. [16] Insert the suppository. Using your gloved finger, push the suppository into your anus. Make sure it goes in about an inch, past your sphincter. Otherwise, it may not stay in. [17] Squeeze your sphincter to keep the suppository inside your body. Squeeze your sphincter muscle together for a few seconds to keep it in. Stay laying down for 5 to 10 minutes while the suppository works. [18] Wash your hands with soap and warm water to remove any germs. Remove your gloves, and wash your hands thoroughly. Use warm water and soap, and scrub your hands for at least 20 seconds. Rinse them under warm water, then dry them with a clean towel. [19] Visit your doctor if your hemorrhoids bleed, hurt, or don’t improve. Most hemorrhoids go away within a week without medical care. However, they can bleed or cause excessive pain sometimes. Additionally, some hemorrhoids are persistent and won’t respond to home treatments. If this happens to you, your doctor can offer you additional treatment options to help you find relief. [20] Let your doctor know that you’ve been treating your hemorrhoid at home using witch hazel. Talk to your doctor if you notice bleeding and are over the age of 40. While this is a common symptom of hemorrhoids, it’s also a symptom of more serious conditions, like colorectal or anal cancer. Try not to worry because it’s likely just hemorrhoids. However, it’s best to see your doctor to make sure. [21] Your risk for colorectal and anal cancer increases as you age. Get immediate medical care for dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting. Try not to worry because you’re likely okay, but these may be symptoms of a more serious condition. Visit your doctor or an urgent care center immediately to get checked out. They’ll help you get the proper treatment to relieve your symptoms. [22] Let your doctor know that you suspected you had hemorrhoids and let them know the symptoms you were experiencing. Let your doctor check your hemorrhoids and do tests, if necessary. Your doctor may do a visual inspection to confirm your diagnosis. If you have internal hemorrhoids, they may do a quick digital exam by feeling for the hemorrhoid using their finger. They may also use a small instrument that lets them see inside, such as a proctoscope. [23] In rare cases, your doctor may decide to do a colonoscopy if they suspect you have a condition other than hemorrhoids. Try not to worry because this test is generally painless, though you’ll likely experience some discomfort. Talk to your doctor about topical treatments for your hemorrhoids. If witch hazel didn’t work, over-the-counter ointments, creams, and suppositories may help. You can find hemorrhoid creams and hydrocortisone suppositories at your local drug store or online. Use them exactly as directed for up to a week. If you still have your hemorrhoid after that, visit your doctor again to ask about other treatments. [24] Read the label before using the product, and make sure you follow all of the directions. Discuss other treatments if your hemorrhoid is interfering with your life. If nothing is helping, your doctor may suggest you try something different to get relief. There are several procedures for treating a hemorrhoid, most of which are minimally invasive. Your doctor may be able to do 1 of the following: [25] Your doctor can cut off the blood supply by doing a rubber band ligation, which means tying rubber bands around the hemorrhoid. This makes it fall off. To shrink your hemorrhoid, your doctor might inject it with a chemical that treats it locally. Your doctor can use heat from a laser or infrared light to shrink and harden your hemorrhoid. In rare cases, your doctor might remove or staple your hemorrhoid to help relieve your symptoms.

<p>Witch hazel is a home remedy used for many skin ailments, and it may help treat your hemorrhoids.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 1" class="reference" id="_ref-1"><a href="#_note-1">[1]</a></sup> To use witch hazel, you either need a witch hazel-alcohol solution or a witch hazel tincture, depending on how you want to apply it to your hemorrhoids and depending on whether your hemorrhoids are internal or external. Then, you can apply your witch hazel either topically or in a suppository. However, it’s best to see your doctor if you have pain, bleeding, or a hemorrhoid that won’t go away.</p>

<a class="anchor" name="Using_Witch_Hazel_Topically_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky steps_first">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>1</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Using_Witch_Hazel_Topically">Using Witch Hazel Topically</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_1">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_25660554ab" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_25660554ab')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 1" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" onload="WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f4/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-1-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript>
<script>WH.performance.clearMarks('image1_rendered'); WH.performance.mark('image1_rendered');</script></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Look for symptoms of hemorrhoids.</b> Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anal canal that can be present either outside or inside the body. They form when too much pressure on on the veins causes them to swell.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 2" class="reference" id="_ref-2"><a href="#_note-2">[2]</a></sup> This can happen when you strain while having a bowel movement, during pregnancy, or as a result of being overweight. Hemorrhoids are a common condition that can often be resolved with home treatment, including witch hazel. Symptoms include the following:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 3" class="reference" id="_ref-3"><a href="#_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Itching, irritation or pain in the anal area.</li>
<li>Bleeding when you have a bowel movement (the blood will be bright red).</li>
<li>A swelling or lump in the anal area.</li>
<li>Check with your doctor before trying home treatment if you are unsure whether your symptoms are the result of hemorrhoids.</li>
</ul>
<script>WH.performance.mark('step1_rendered');</script>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Clean your anal area before treating your hemorrhoids.</b> Bathe or shower daily to keep your anal area clean. Baths are preferable to showers because it allows the area to sit in warm water for longer. You don't need to use soap, but use warm to hot water. Be gentle when cleaning your anal area, as scrubbing harder can cause irritation.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 4" class="reference" id="_ref-4"><a href="#_note-4">[4]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Try a sitz bath to make things easier. These are inexpensive tubs that fit over your toilet to make it easier to soak your anal area. Use plain warm water or add Epsom salt to help soothe your hemorrhoids. Then, sit in your sitz bath for 10-15 minutes.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_3c9fa6b0e1" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_3c9fa6b0e1')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 3" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/f/f3/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-3-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Don't use a towel to dry your anal area because it can hurt.</b> After drying off the rest of your body, use a hair dryer to dry off your anal area. Hold the hair dryer at least 8 inches (20 cm) away from your skin and keep it moving. Rubbing with a towel can make the problem worse.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 5" class="reference" id="_ref-5"><a href="#_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>Don’t direct the hair dryer at 1 spot, as this might burn your skin.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Use a cloth to blot the witch hazel directly onto your hemorrhoid.</b> Use a clean piece of cloth. Soak it in a witch hazel-alcohol extract. Blot it gently on the affected area. You can hold it on for a few minutes.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 6" class="reference" id="_ref-6"><a href="#_note-6">[6]</a></sup><ul>
<li>If you prefer, you can use pre-made witch hazel pads, made specifically for use with hemorrhoids.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 7" class="reference" id="_ref-7"><a href="#_note-7">[7]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>This application is best for external hemorrhoids, as it only reaches the outer part of your anus. Internal hemorrhoids are ones that remain inside your anal cavity, while external ones bulge out past your sphincter.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 8" class="reference" id="_ref-8"><a href="#_note-8">[8]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_1_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Let the area air dry for a few minutes before getting dressed.</b> Once you remove the cloth, let the area air dry for a few minutes before putting your clothes back on. If you put your clothes on over wet skin, it may not dry all of the way.
<ul>
<li>Wear cotton underwear because it’s more breathable.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>

<a class="anchor" name="Creating_a_Homemade_Witch_Hazel_Suppository_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>2</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="Creating_a_Homemade_Witch_Hazel_Suppository">Creating a Homemade Witch Hazel Suppository</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_2">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" height="546" id="img_69a55ef9c7" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_69a55ef9c7')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 6" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/19/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-6-Version-2.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Mix a teaspoon of witch hazel tincture with a teaspoon of cocoa butter.</b> In a small bowl, place a teaspoon each of witch hazel tincture and cocoa butter. Stir them together. You should be able to find both at your local drug store, though you may need to visit a natural health store instead.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 9" class="reference" id="_ref-9"><a href="#_note-9">[9]</a></sup>
<ul>
<li>This application works best for internal hemorrhoids. You can use this treatment three times a day.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 10" class="reference" id="_ref-10"><a href="#_note-10">[10]</a></sup>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg" height="546" id="img_e427c52bea" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_e427c52bea')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 7" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/5/58/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-7.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Form the mixture into a suppository.</b> Shape the mixture into a small pill oblong pill shape. If you're having trouble shaping it, place the mixture in a small amount of plastic wrap, and twist the plastic wrap to shape the pill. If it's not in plastic wrap, place it in a small, covered bowl.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 11" class="reference" id="_ref-11"><a href="#_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg" height="546" id="img_b79361c8ec" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_b79361c8ec')</script>
</div>
<noscript><img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 8" class="whcdn content-fill" height="546" src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/7/7c/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-8.jpg" width="728"/></noscript></a></div>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Freeze the suppository for at least 1-2 hours.</b> Put the suppository on a clean dish. Then, set it in your freezer and leave it there until it’s frozen. This should take at least 1-2 hours, but it could take longer.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 12" class="reference" id="_ref-12"><a href="#_note-12">[12]</a></sup>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="hasimage">
<div class="mwimg largeimage floatcenter" style="max-width:728px"><a class="image lightbox" data-href="/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-9.jpg?ajax=true&aid=307429" href="#/Image:Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-9.jpg"><div class="content-spacer">
<img alt="Image titled Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids Step 9" class="whcdn content-fill" data-src="https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/c/c2/Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-9.jpg/aid307429-v4-728px-Use-Witch-Hazel-to-Reduce-Hemorrhoids-Step-9.jpg" height="546" id="img_08a98ec682" width="728"/><script>WH.shared.addScrollLoadItem('img_08a98ec682')</script>

<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Remove the suppository from the freezer.</b> Once the suppository has hardened, take it out of the freezer. Unwrap it if it's in plastic wrap, or take the lid off the bowl. <a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_6"></a><div class="step">

<a class="stepanchor" name="step_2_9"></a><div class="step">

Rinse them under warm water, then dry them with a clean towel.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 19" class="reference" id="_ref-19"><a href="#_note-19">[19]</a></sup>

<a class="anchor" name="When_to_Seek_Medical_Care_sub"></a><div class="section steps sticky">
<h3>
<div class="altblock"><label class="method_label">Method</label> <span>3</span>
</div>
<span class="mw-headline" id="When_to_Seek_Medical_Care">When to Seek Medical Care</span>
</h3>
<div class="section_text" id="steps_3">
<ol class="steps_list_2">
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 1" class="step_num">1</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_1"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Visit your doctor if your hemorrhoids bleed, hurt, or don’t improve.</b> Most hemorrhoids go away within a week without medical care. However, they can bleed or cause excessive pain sometimes. Additionally, some hemorrhoids are persistent and won’t respond to home treatments. If this happens to you, your doctor can offer you additional treatment options to help you find relief.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 20" class="reference" id="_ref-20"><a href="#_note-20">[20]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Let your doctor know that you’ve been treating your hemorrhoid at home using witch hazel.

</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="green_box">
<p><b>Tip:</b> It’s normal to feel embarrassed about a hemorrhoid, but they’re very common. Your doctor has seen a lot of hemorrhoids and may have had one themself. Try not to feel nervous about discussing your symptoms.</p>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 2" class="step_num">2</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_2"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to your doctor if you notice bleeding and are over the age of 40.</b> While this is a common symptom of hemorrhoids, it’s also a symptom of more serious conditions, like colorectal or anal cancer. Try not to worry because it’s likely just hemorrhoids. However, it’s best to see your doctor to make sure.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 21" class="reference" id="_ref-21"><a href="#_note-21">[21]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Your risk for colorectal and anal cancer increases as you age.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 3" class="step_num">3</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_3"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Get immediate medical care for dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting.</b> Try not to worry because you’re likely okay, but these may be symptoms of a more serious condition. Visit your doctor or an urgent care center immediately to get checked out. They’ll help you get the proper treatment to relieve your symptoms.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 22" class="reference" id="_ref-22"><a href="#_note-22">[22]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Let your doctor know that you suspected you had hemorrhoids and let them know the symptoms you were experiencing.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 4" class="step_num">4</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_4"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Let your doctor check your hemorrhoids and do tests, if necessary.</b> Your doctor may do a visual inspection to confirm your diagnosis. If you have internal hemorrhoids, they may do a quick digital exam by feeling for the hemorrhoid using their finger. They may also use a small instrument that lets them see inside, such as a proctoscope.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 23" class="reference" id="_ref-23"><a href="#_note-23">[23]</a></sup><ul>
<li>In rare cases, your doctor may decide to do a colonoscopy if they suspect you have a condition other than hemorrhoids. Try not to worry because this test is generally painless, though you’ll likely experience some discomfort.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li>
<div aria-label="Step 5" class="step_num">5</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_5"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Talk to your doctor about topical treatments for your hemorrhoids.</b> If witch hazel didn’t work, over-the-counter ointments, creams, and suppositories may help. You can find hemorrhoid creams and hydrocortisone suppositories at your local drug store or online. Use them exactly as directed for up to a week. If you still have your hemorrhoid after that, visit your doctor again to ask about other treatments.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 24" class="reference" id="_ref-24"><a href="#_note-24">[24]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Read the label before using the product, and make sure you follow all of the directions.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
<li class="final_li">
<div aria-label="Step 6" class="step_num">6</div>
<a class="stepanchor" name="step_3_6"></a><div class="step">
<b class="whb">Discuss other treatments if your hemorrhoid is interfering with your life.</b> If nothing is helping, your doctor may suggest you try something different to get relief. There are several procedures for treating a hemorrhoid, most of which are minimally invasive. Your doctor may be able to do 1 of the following:<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 25" class="reference" id="_ref-25"><a href="#_note-25">[25]</a></sup><ul>
<li>Your doctor can cut off the blood supply by doing a rubber band ligation, which means tying rubber bands around the hemorrhoid. This makes it fall off.</li>
<li>To shrink your hemorrhoid, your doctor might inject it with a chemical that treats it locally.</li>
<li>Your doctor can use heat from a laser or infrared light to shrink and harden your hemorrhoid.</li>
<li>In rare cases, your doctor might remove or staple your hemorrhoid to help relieve your symptoms.</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</li>
</ol>
<div class="clearall"></div>
</div>
</div>

<div class="section_text" id="tips">
<ul>
<li>Witch hazel is an astringent, which means it’s drying. It helps treat hemorrhoids by drying and shrinking them.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 26" class="reference" id="_ref-26"><a href="#_note-26">[26]</a></sup>

<div class="section_text" id="warnings">
<ul>
<li>Always check with your doctor to confirm your problem is hemorrhoids. Though hemorrhoids can often be treated at home, you should make sure you don't have a more serious problem. Additionally, if your hemorrhoids are particularly bad, your doctor can offer some in-office treatments to lessen your discomfort.</li>
<li>When you apply it topically, witch hazel can lead to irritation and itchiness if you are allergic to it.<sup aria-label="Link to Reference 27" class="reference" id="_ref-27"><a href="#_note-27">[27]</a></sup>
</li>
<li>If you find blood after wiping or if defecation is painful, you should contact physician.</li>
</ul>

<p>To reduce external hemorrhoids by using witch hazel, start by gently cleaning your anal area in the bath or shower. Afterwards, dry the area with a hair dryer instead of a towel in order to prevent further irritation. Then, soak a clean piece of cloth in witch hazel and blot it gently on the affected area. Alternatively, use pre-made witch hazel pads, made specifically for use with hemorrhoids. Finally, let the area air dry for a few minutes before getting dressed. <span id="summary_last_sentence">For more advice from our Naturopathic reviewer, including how to remove internal hemorrhoids with a witch hazel suppository, keep reading.</span><span class="sumpos_bottom" id="summary_position"></span></p>

    "step": [
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Using Witch Hazel Topically",
            "position": 1,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Look for symptoms of hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anal canal that can be present either outside or inside the body. They form when too much pressure on on the veins causes them to swell.[2] This can happen when you strain while having a bowel movement, during pregnancy, or as a result of being overweight. Hemorrhoids are a common condition that can often be resolved with home treatment, including witch hazel. Symptoms include the following:[3]\nItching, irritation or pain in the anal area.\nBleeding when you have a bowel movement (the blood will be bright red).\nA swelling or lump in the anal area.\nCheck with your doctor before trying home treatment if you are unsure whether your symptoms are the result of hemorrhoids."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Clean your anal area before treating your hemorrhoids. Bathe or shower daily to keep your anal area clean. Baths are preferable to showers because it allows the area to sit in warm water for longer. You don't need to use soap, but use warm to hot water. Be gentle when cleaning your anal area, as scrubbing harder can cause irritation.[4]Try a sitz bath to make things easier. These are inexpensive tubs that fit over your toilet to make it easier to soak your anal area. Use plain warm water or add Epsom salt to help soothe your hemorrhoids. Then, sit in your sitz bath for 10-15 minutes."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Don't use a towel to dry your anal area because it can hurt. After drying off the rest of your body, use a hair dryer to dry off your anal area. Hold the hair dryer at least 8 inches (20\u00a0cm) away from your skin and keep it moving. Rubbing with a towel can make the problem worse.[5]\nDon\u2019t direct the hair dryer at 1 spot, as this might burn your skin."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use a cloth to blot the witch hazel directly onto your hemorrhoid. Use a clean piece of cloth. Soak it in a witch hazel-alcohol extract. Blot it gently on the affected area. You can hold it on for a few minutes.[6]If you prefer, you can use pre-made witch hazel pads, made specifically for use with hemorrhoids.[7]\nThis application is best for external hemorrhoids, as it only reaches the outer part of your anus. Internal hemorrhoids are ones that remain inside your anal cavity, while external ones bulge out past your sphincter.[8]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Let the area air dry for a few minutes before getting dressed. Once you remove the cloth, let the area air dry for a few minutes before putting your clothes back on. If you put your clothes on over wet skin, it may not dry all of the way.\nWear cotton underwear because it\u2019s more breathable."
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "Creating a Homemade Witch Hazel Suppository",
            "position": 2,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Mix a teaspoon of witch hazel tincture with a teaspoon of cocoa butter. In a small bowl, place a teaspoon each of witch hazel tincture and cocoa butter. Stir them together. You should be able to find both at your local drug store, though you may need to visit a natural health store instead.[9]\nThis application works best for internal hemorrhoids. You can use this treatment three times a day.[10]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Form the mixture into a suppository. Shape the mixture into a small pill oblong pill shape. If you're having trouble shaping it, place the mixture in a small amount of plastic wrap, and twist the plastic wrap to shape the pill. If it's not in plastic wrap, place it in a small, covered bowl.[11]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Freeze the suppository for at least 1-2 hours. Put the suppository on a clean dish. Then, set it in your freezer and leave it there until it\u2019s frozen. This should take at least 1-2 hours, but it could take longer.[12]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Put on a glove or finger cot. Wear hand protection to keep your fingers germ-free. This step is optional, but it will help prevent you from getting bacteria under your nails or in the folds of your skin.[13]\nYou don't have to use one, as long as you wash your hands thoroughly afterwards."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Remove the suppository from the freezer. Once the suppository has hardened, take it out of the freezer. Unwrap it if it's in plastic wrap, or take the lid off the bowl. If it seems too large, you can cut it in half, and save half for another time by putting it back in plastic wrap and back in the freezer.[14]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Use lubrication to make the suppository go in easily. Either apply a lubrication such as KY Jelly, or use your finger to wet your anal area with a little bit of cold water. This will help you avoid any discomfort when you insert the suppository. Plus, it will go in further.[15]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 7,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Lie down on your side and open your buttocks. Lay down on your side. Bend the knee of your top leg, and angle it towards the bed. Let the other leg stay out straight. Use one hand to lift up one side of your buttocks.[16]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 8,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Insert the suppository. Using your gloved finger, push the suppository into your anus. Make sure it goes in about an inch, past your sphincter. Otherwise, it may not stay in.[17]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 9,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Squeeze your sphincter to keep the suppository inside your body. Squeeze your sphincter muscle together for a few seconds to keep it in. Stay laying down for 5 to 10 minutes while the suppository works.[18]"
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 10,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Wash your hands with soap and warm water to remove any germs. Remove your gloves, and wash your hands thoroughly. Use warm water and soap, and scrub your hands for at least 20 seconds. Rinse them under warm water, then dry them with a clean towel.[19]"
                    }
                }
            ]
        },
        {
            "@type": "HowToSection",
            "name": "When to Seek Medical Care",
            "position": 3,
            "itemListElement": [
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 1,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Visit your doctor if your hemorrhoids bleed, hurt, or don\u2019t improve. Most hemorrhoids go away within a week without medical care. However, they can bleed or cause excessive pain sometimes. Additionally, some hemorrhoids are persistent and won\u2019t respond to home treatments. If this happens to you, your doctor can offer you additional treatment options to help you find relief.[20]Let your doctor know that you\u2019ve been treating your hemorrhoid at home using witch hazel.\n\nTip: It\u2019s normal to feel embarrassed about a hemorrhoid, but they\u2019re very common. Your doctor has seen a lot of hemorrhoids and may have had one themself. Try not to feel nervous about discussing your symptoms."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 2,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Talk to your doctor if you notice bleeding and are over the age of 40. While this is a common symptom of hemorrhoids, it\u2019s also a symptom of more serious conditions, like colorectal or anal cancer. Try not to worry because it\u2019s likely just hemorrhoids. However, it\u2019s best to see your doctor to make sure.[21]Your risk for colorectal and anal cancer increases as you age."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 3,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Get immediate medical care for dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting. Try not to worry because you\u2019re likely okay, but these may be symptoms of a more serious condition. Visit your doctor or an urgent care center immediately to get checked out. They\u2019ll help you get the proper treatment to relieve your symptoms.[22]Let your doctor know that you suspected you had hemorrhoids and let them know the symptoms you were experiencing."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 4,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Let your doctor check your hemorrhoids and do tests, if necessary. Your doctor may do a visual inspection to confirm your diagnosis. If you have internal hemorrhoids, they may do a quick digital exam by feeling for the hemorrhoid using their finger. They may also use a small instrument that lets them see inside, such as a proctoscope.[23]In rare cases, your doctor may decide to do a colonoscopy if they suspect you have a condition other than hemorrhoids. Try not to worry because this test is generally painless, though you\u2019ll likely experience some discomfort."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 5,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Talk to your doctor about topical treatments for your hemorrhoids. If witch hazel didn\u2019t work, over-the-counter ointments, creams, and suppositories may help. You can find hemorrhoid creams and hydrocortisone suppositories at your local drug store or online. Use them exactly as directed for up to a week. If you still have your hemorrhoid after that, visit your doctor again to ask about other treatments.[24]Read the label before using the product, and make sure you follow all of the directions."
                    }
                },
                {
                    "@type": "HowToStep",
                    "position": 6,
                    "itemListElement": {
                        "@type": "HowToDirection",
                        "position": 1,
                        "text": "Discuss other treatments if your hemorrhoid is interfering with your life. If nothing is helping, your doctor may suggest you try something different to get relief. title: How to Use Witch Hazel to Reduce Hemorrhoids
content_html:
Look for symptoms of hemorrhoids. Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the anal canal that can be present either outside or inside the body. They form when too much pressure on on the veins causes them to swell.[2] This can happen when you strain while having a bowel movement, during pregnancy, or as a result of being overweight. Hemorrhoids are a common condition that can often be resolved with home treatment, including witch hazel. Symptoms include the following:[3]
  • Itching, irritation or pain in the anal area.
  • Bleeding when you have a bowel movement (the blood will be bright red).
  • A swelling or lump in the anal area.
  • Check with your doctor before trying home treatment if you are unsure whether your symptoms are the result of hemorrhoids.
Clean your anal area before treating your hemorrhoids. Bathe or shower daily to keep your anal area clean. Baths are preferable to showers because it allows the area to sit in warm water for longer. You don't need to use soap, but use warm to hot water. Be gentle when cleaning your anal area, as scrubbing harder can cause irritation.[4]
  • Try a sitz bath to make things easier. These are inexpensive tubs that fit over your toilet to make it easier to soak your anal area. Use plain warm water or add Epsom salt to help soothe your hemorrhoids. Then, sit in your sitz bath for 10-15 minutes.
Don't use a towel to dry your anal area because it can hurt. After drying off the rest of your body, use a hair dryer to dry off your anal area. Hold the hair dryer at least 8 inches (20 cm) away from your skin and keep it moving. Rubbing with a towel can make the problem worse.[5]
  • Don’t direct the hair dryer at 1 spot, as this might burn your skin.
Use a cloth to blot the witch hazel directly onto your hemorrhoid. Use a clean piece of cloth. Soak it in a witch hazel-alcohol extract. Blot it gently on the affected area. You can hold it on for a few minutes.[6]
  • If you prefer, you can use pre-made witch hazel pads, made specifically for use with hemorrhoids.[7]
  • This application is best for external hemorrhoids, as it only reaches the outer part of your anus. Internal hemorrhoids are ones that remain inside your anal cavity, while external ones bulge out past your sphincter.[8]
Let the area air dry for a few minutes before getting dressed. Once you remove the cloth, let the area air dry for a few minutes before putting your clothes back on. If you put your clothes on over wet skin, it may not dry all of the way.
  • Wear cotton underwear because it’s more breathable.
Mix a teaspoon of witch hazel tincture with a teaspoon of cocoa butter. In a small bowl, place a teaspoon each of witch hazel tincture and cocoa butter. Stir them together. You should be able to find both at your local drug store, though you may need to visit a natural health store instead.[9]
  • This application works best for internal hemorrhoids. You can use this treatment three times a day.[10]
Form the mixture into a suppository. Shape the mixture into a small pill oblong pill shape. If you're having trouble shaping it, place the mixture in a small amount of plastic wrap, and twist the plastic wrap to shape the pill. If it's not in plastic wrap, place it in a small, covered bowl.[11]
Freeze the suppository for at least 1-2 hours. Put the suppository on a clean dish. Then, set it in your freezer and leave it there until it’s frozen. This should take at least 1-2 hours, but it could take longer.[12]
Put on a glove or finger cot. Wear hand protection to keep your fingers germ-free. This step is optional, but it will help prevent you from getting bacteria under your nails or in the folds of your skin.[13]
  • You don't have to use one, as long as you wash your hands thoroughly afterwards.
Remove the suppository from the freezer. Once the suppository has hardened, take it out of the freezer. Unwrap it if it's in plastic wrap, or take the lid off the bowl. If it seems too large, you can cut it in half, and save half for another time by putting it back in plastic wrap and back in the freezer.[14]
Use lubrication to make the suppository go in easily. Either apply a lubrication such as KY Jelly, or use your finger to wet your anal area with a little bit of cold water. This will help you avoid any discomfort when you insert the suppository. Plus, it will go in further.[15]
Lie down on your side and open your buttocks. Lay down on your side. Bend the knee of your top leg, and angle it towards the bed. Let the other leg stay out straight. Use one hand to lift up one side of your buttocks.[16]
Insert the suppository. Using your gloved finger, push the suppository into your anus. Make sure it goes in about an inch, past your sphincter. Otherwise, it may not stay in.[17]
Squeeze your sphincter to keep the suppository inside your body. Squeeze your sphincter muscle together for a few seconds to keep it in. Stay laying down for 5 to 10 minutes while the suppository works.[18]
Wash your hands with soap and warm water to remove any germs. Remove your gloves, and wash your hands thoroughly. Use warm water and soap, and scrub your hands for at least 20 seconds. Rinse them under warm water, then dry them with a clean towel.[19]
Visit your doctor if your hemorrhoids bleed, hurt, or don’t improve. Most hemorrhoids go away within a week without medical care. However, they can bleed or cause excessive pain sometimes. Additionally, some hemorrhoids are persistent and won’t respond to home treatments. If this happens to you, your doctor can offer you additional treatment options to help you find relief.[20]
  • Let your doctor know that you’ve been treating your hemorrhoid at home using witch hazel.
Talk to your doctor if you notice bleeding and are over the age of 40. While this is a common symptom of hemorrhoids, it’s also a symptom of more serious conditions, like colorectal or anal cancer. Try not to worry because it’s likely just hemorrhoids. However, it’s best to see your doctor to make sure.[21]
  • Your risk for colorectal and anal cancer increases as you age.
Get immediate medical care for dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting. Try not to worry because you’re likely okay, but these may be symptoms of a more serious condition. Visit your doctor or an urgent care center immediately to get checked out. They’ll help you get the proper treatment to relieve your symptoms.[22]
  • Let your doctor know that you suspected you had hemorrhoids and let them know the symptoms you were experiencing.
Let your doctor check your hemorrhoids and do tests, if necessary. Your doctor may do a visual inspection to confirm your diagnosis. If you have internal hemorrhoids, they may do a quick digital exam by feeling for the hemorrhoid using their finger. They may also use a small instrument that lets them see inside, such as a proctoscope.[23]
  • In rare cases, your doctor may decide to do a colonoscopy if they suspect you have a condition other than hemorrhoids. Try not to worry because this test is generally painless, though you’ll likely experience some discomfort.
Talk to your doctor about topical treatments for your hemorrhoids. If witch hazel didn’t work, over-the-counter ointments, creams, and suppositories may help. You can find hemorrhoid creams and hydrocortisone suppositories at your local drug store or online. Use them exactly as directed for up to a week. If you still have your hemorrhoid after that, visit your doctor again to ask about other treatments.[24]
  • Read the label before using the product, and make sure you follow all of the directions.
Discuss other treatments if your hemorrhoid is interfering with your life. If nothing is helping, your doctor may suggest you try something different to get relief. There are several procedures for treating a hemorrhoid, most of which are minimally invasive. Your doctor may be able to do 1 of the following:[25]
  • Your doctor can cut off the blood supply by doing a rubber band ligation, which means tying rubber bands around the hemorrhoid. This makes it fall off.
  • To shrink your hemorrhoid, your doctor might inject it with a chemical that treats it locally.
  • Your doctor can use heat from a laser or infrared light to shrink and harden your hemorrhoid.
  • In rare cases, your doctor might remove or staple your hemorrhoid to help relieve your symptoms.
